title: Inhibition/Exhibition I
description:
“Il ne faut donc pas dire que notre corps est dans l'espace ni d'ailleurs qu'il est dans le temps. Il habite l'espace et le temps.” 
“Thus, we must not say that our body is in space, nor for that matter in time. It inhabits space and time.”
Maurice Merleau‑Ponty 

Inhibition/Exhibition I (“InExI”), for amplified instrument (electric guitar in this version) and the audio spacer, is a live electroacoustic performance in a dark room with an 8-speaker configuration. The attached recording is a binaural rendering, yet it is best approached by imagining the possibility of moving through the space and perceiving the work from changing vantage points, rather than following the score or a video. 

The audio spacer (github.com/gurshafriri/audio-spacer) is a Max/MSP-based tool with controls to record, slice, shift, and disperse sound within a spatial field. In InExI, it functions both as the primary instrument and as the source of the musical material, process, and form. 

Neural inhibition and predictive coding shape how we experience light and sound. We lock visuals in space to allow a sense of stability for our body; we eliminate static sound and emphasize its temporal variation to track time. The slicing, shifting, and redistribution of guitar sounds as performed by the audio spacer allow the listener to suspend both habitual processing and intellectual analysis. Combined with the dark room as a visual constraint, they might find themselves re-applying visuospatial synthesis patterns on sound in place of light, bypassing some of the primal inhibitions we impose on it. 

As we attempt to reconstruct stability from whatever we can grasp, even microtonal harmonies and irrational meters resonate with our memories of musical constructs and become unexpected anchors. Both the audio spacer as a tool and InExI as a piece explore this reconstruction of sound in space as a means of, if only for a moment, disorienting our temporal and spatial perception and triggering a new perspective on experience.

title: Mobile
description:
“To most people who look at a mobile,
it’s no more than a series of flat objects that move.
To a few, though, it may be poetry.”
— Alexander Calder

Studies show that we tend to be remarkably accurate at identifying the average pitch within a series of random pitches. This insight inspired Mobile, a piece for mixed ensemble built on a new system of pitch organization — one centered on the average pitch rather than the tonic or fundamental frequency familiar from tonal or spectral music.

Like a Calder mobile, the piece is constructed from a set of carefully balanced “objects.” Each object averages to a particular pitch, and the ensemble of objects, in turn, revolves around D4. Most of these objects were first created using Averager (github.com/gurshafriri/averager), a Max for Live MIDI device built as a computer-aided composition tool while composing the work. Averager generates random pitch sets whose average matches a target pitch. The user can control the number of notes, the range around the average, and several playback parameters for live or studio contexts.

Composing with this approach turns pitch manipulation into a complex act of equilibrium: every note shifted upward or downward requires a counterbalance elsewhere — just as a sculptor must adjust each element of a mobile before allowing it to move freely in space. Timbre, contour, rhythm, and pace take on a larger role as tools for shaping the piece’s form and flow.

This method of average-based organization echoes the same principle of balance that guided composers from cantus firmus to dodecaphony: what rises must eventually fall, and vice versa. In that sense, the twelve-tone technique can be seen as a flat and fixed realization of an average-based system — an ever-balanced set of pitches that defines motion through stability. Is Mobile a static or a moving work of art? The listener may change their mind throughout, perhaps reaching balance by the end.

title: Tabur
description:
“Shape the clay into a vessel;
It is the space within that makes it useful.
“

Tabur, for three percussionists and choir, investigates the shared ground between two seemingly distant sound worlds: the human voice and percussion.

This relationship is revealed through the extensive use of sustain-based percussion instruments — gongs, Tibetan bowls, vibraphone, and bass drum. All gongs and bowls underwent preliminary spectral analysis; their unique spectra serve as the harmonic model for the choir’s pitch organization, blending the two worlds from the very outset.

As a counterpoint, the piece focuses on the percussive nature of speech — verbal consonants as siblings of attack-based percussion. The singers recite Hebrew words, spoken freely or in pitch, sometimes sung, and shaped into fricative textures that intertwine with the instrumental gestures.

The chosen text, drawn from Lao Tzu, resonates with the work’s musical intention. It reflects on the isness of what lies in between — the space of a room, the cavity of a bowl. The consonants and percussive strikes represent what is: active, tangible, finite. The vowels and sustained tones embody what isn’t: resonance, aftermath, the reaction of space to changes in matter. Fricative sounds remind us that there is no real difference between the two — nor between voice and percussion, human and instrument.
